verses.text: Listen, my children, to a father's instruction; pay attention and gain understanding.
verses.comment: The term 'children' here refers to the pupils or disciples who receive wisdom, echoing the biblical tradition of passing wisdom from one generation to another.

verses.text: For I give you good teaching; do not forsake my instruction.
verses.comment: Emphasizes the authoritative nature of instruction, reminding readers of the necessity to adhere to revealed wisdom.

verses.text: For I, too, was a son to my father, tender and cherished by my mother.
verses.comment: The text draws on familial legacy, subtly implying the importance of tradition in transmitting truth.

verses.text: He taught me and said to me, 'Let your heart hold fast my words; keep my commandments and live.'
verses.comment: The phrase 'keep my commandments and live' has strong echoes of Deut. 6:2, showing how obedience leads to life—a foreshadowing of later spiritual teachings on following Christ.

verses.text: Get wisdom; get understanding. Do not forget nor turn away from the words of my mouth.
verses.comment: The pursuit of wisdom is a life-long duty. The word 'get' indicates active seeking, paralleling the New Testament call to seek kingdom truths (Matt. 6:33).

verses.text: Do not forsake her, and she will preserve you; love her, and she will protect you.
verses.comment: Wisdom is personified as a woman, an image later deepened by Christ, the wisdom of God (1 Cor. 1:24).

verses.text: The beginning of wisdom is this: Get wisdom. Though it cost all you have, get understanding.
verses.comment: Highlights the supreme value of wisdom, urging total commitment, similar to Jesus' teaching about the pearl of great price (Matt. 13:45-46).

verses.text: Prize her highly, and she will exalt you; she will honor you if you embrace her.
verses.comment: The reciprocal relationship with wisdom encourages active participation, mirroring the later call to embrace spiritual life through sacraments and tradition.

verses.text: She will place on your head a garland of grace; she will bestow on you a crown of glory.
verses.comment: The 'crown of glory' foreshadows heavenly rewards for faithfulness, drawing spiritual meaning from obedience and perseverance.

verses.text: Hear, my son, and accept my sayings, and the years of your life will be many.
verses.comment: Obedience to wisdom leads to long life, which encompasses both literal and spiritual blessing.

verses.text: I have instructed you in the way of wisdom; I have led you along straight paths.
verses.comment: The 'straight paths' symbolize moral clarity and preparedness, connecting to the preparatory role of John the Baptist (Matt. 3:3).

verses.text: When you walk, your steps will not be hindered; when you run, you will not stumble.
verses.comment: Faithful adherence to wisdom prevents spiritual downfall, reflecting the life of virtue taught throughout Scripture.

verses.text: Hold on to instruction; do not let go. Guard her, for she is your life.
verses.comment: Echoes Deuteronomy’s call to hold fast to the Word. Instruction is depicted as a source of life.

verses.text: Do not enter the path of the wicked, nor walk in the way of evil men.
verses.comment: Warns against moral compromise, calling believers to discernment and separation from evil.

verses.text: Avoid it; do not go near it. Turn away from it and pass by.
verses.comment: Total avoidance of evil is urged, paralleling the call to holiness as a separation from sin.

verses.text: For they cannot sleep unless they do evil; they are robbed of rest unless they make someone fall.
verses.comment: Describes the restless and enslaving nature of sin, setting a vivid contrast with the peace given through righteousness.

verses.text: For they eat the bread of wickedness and drink the wine of violence.
verses.comment: Bread and wine imagery, here used negatively, later becomes reversed in the New Testament as symbols of divine grace (Matt. 26:26-28).

verses.text: But the path of the righteous is like the light of dawn, shining brighter and brighter until full day.
verses.comment: Increasing light evokes spiritual growth and the coming of the true Light, Christ Himself.

verses.text: The way of the wicked is like deep darkness; they do not know over what they stumble.
verses.comment: Darkness symbolizes spiritual blindness, highlighted in the New Testament as rejection of Christ.

verses.text: My son, pay attention to my words; incline your ear to my sayings.
verses.comment: A renewed call to focused listening, foreshadowing the demand for interior receptiveness to divine revelation.

verses.text: Let them not escape your sight; keep them within your heart.
verses.comment: Heart-centered piety underpins Old/New Testament spirituality (see Matt. 5:8).

verses.text: For they are life to those who find them, and health to all their flesh.
verses.comment: Describes the holistic blessing of wisdom—both spiritual and physical.

verses.text: Guard your heart above all else, for from it flow the springs of life.
verses.comment: The heart as a vital center is a key biblical theme, prefiguring later teachings on interior sanctification and the indwelling of the Spirit.

verses.text: Put away from you crooked speech, and put devious talk far from you.
verses.comment: Moral discipline is shown in language as well as action; speech reveals the state of the heart (Matt. 12:34).

verses.text: Let your eyes look straight ahead; fix your gaze directly before you.
verses.comment: Focus on the true path parallels the call to perseverance in the faith journey.

verses.text: Ponder the path of your feet, and all your ways will be sure.
verses.comment: Intentional living—examining one’s path—reflects the tradition of regular spiritual self-examination.

verses.text: Do not turn to the right or to the left; turn your foot away from evil.
verses.comment: The command to avoid deviation recalls Israel’s call to covenant faithfulness and foreshadows the enduring moral teaching of the Church.
